page.lettertext:
fol.176r
[To my L.]
T
re
r
May yt please yo
r
good L
p
. For answere to yo
r
L
re
of
e 3
d
of this p
nt
, I
can signifie no more of
e
States
preparation, then I have donne already. They
have alwayes complyned, and so they do yet, that they are not made acquainted
w
th
hir
Highnes
resolutions knowing nothinge yet for certaine of the troupes that
shalbe sent, of the number of hir shipps, of the tyme and place of their meetinge,
or other needfull particularities: Neverthelesse in regarde of
eir desire to seconde
t
service, and
t
they may not be blamed for any backwardnes here, they have
already ordained (as I wryt unto yo
r
L
p
e 7 of this month) that of 10 of their
best and greatest shippes, eyther all, or some parte shall repayre unto the Downes,
assoone as they are armed; but yet I am perswaded, unlesse the certainty be
greater of her Ma
ts
proceedings then yet appeareth unto them, they will but
temporise at home, and (as I may conjecture) will not willingly by
e first
that shall sett their shippes to sea.
M
r
Caron
(as I am privately informed)
hath donne them to witt, that 14 of hir shippes are dispatched towards
Pli
m
outh
,
but yet for ought I can perceave they are very lyttle stirred w
th
that advertisem
t
from him, dowbting (as I do suspecte)
t
it is but given owt, to tolle them faster
forwarde, w
ch
perhaps they thincke
e rather, because nothinge is wrytten of
those shippes unto me; Although I had yowr l
re
by their Agents c
o
veyance, and
it was dated as lately as his. It was my sute unto yo
r
L
p
in all my
former l
re
s,
t
for the better parfourmance of my charge, and to satisfy the
States in that w
ch
they requyre, I might have knowne expresly and directly
aswell what forces hir Highnes intended for hir part to fournish to this voyage
as what she doth expect should be donne by them here; or in case
t
nothinge
were determined, to insinuate yet somwhat whereby I might be hable to inter-
tayne them here the whyle. Howbeyt yo
r
L
p
knoweth
t
from the time
that I parted from home till this tyme I had never any aunsweare to any
point that I
posed. Onely by yo
r
l
re
of the 7 of July, I was injoyned to
reco
m
ende unto the States, those particular demands w
ch
were
dl
M
r
Caron
but yt was not signifyed to me what those demaunds might importe: Uppon
occasion whereof I am humbly to beseech yow, that in these affayres of hir Ma
ty
I may alwayes be instructed boath precisely and by wrytinge, to what effect
I shall negotiate, and that I may not be referred to knowe my message of
em w
th
whom I should negotiate. For to be playne in this case, they do very much mar-
vayle, and speake of yt often, to see me left so longe here w
th
out any information
especially in these matters
t
are of such consequence, and for w
ch
I was sent
expresly unto them. They tell me also rowndly, that considering I am p
nt
, yt is
not their order, to take onely notice of such messages from their Agent, and
uppon this reporte to deale w
th
their Provinces, but they must be reco
m
ended, as
desyred from hir Ma
ty
by hir l
re
s unto them or by me that am her servant
and purposely imployed. And in effect yt wilbe hard for hir Highnes to be
served as she woulde be yf there be no more care of hir Ministers credit.
I will not amplifie this poynt, because yo
r
L
p
in yo
r
wisdome doth knowe
what is meete, and will pardonne me a litle yf I speake w
th
some plainenes
when I feele my selfe encombred wth the burden of my service for want of
dew information. They have
ddl
unto me a transcript of hir Ma
tyes
demaundes
in which I doe not dowbt but they deale withall sincerity in delivering me
the right demands, but yet I have reason to be scrupulous how farre I should
give credit to that w
ch
they exhibit, where things are not specifyed to me in
my l
re
s: For I see very now that in these dema
u
des, conferring some
poynts w
th
yo
r
L
ps
l
re
there is apparant variance: For where yo
r
L
p
doth certify that there were twelve shipps at
e least required of them
fol.176v
there are but 10 sett downe in wrytng, and lykewise for the place of their R
endez vous
it is to them assigned to be at
Dover,
or the Downes, where yo
r
L
p
de
clareth
that they are looked for at
Portesmouth
. I have sent you here inclosed a
copy of
those dema
u
des as I receaved them here of them; Moreover I was in some
doubt as
I wryt unto yo
r
L
p
whither they stood styll in force, because there follow
ed a present
countermaunde, which though you shewe to have bin frustrate by hir Hig
hnes
approbation of M
r
Carons dilligence in making his dispatch upon the first
motion
yet
t
was more then I was informed, or then the States at
t
tyme woul
d seem
to understande: What their aunswere was here to every poynt apart, I
advertised your L
p
the 21 of the last, and I did yt as beco
m
ed, w
th
a fay
thfull
relation being ready uppon my perill to justify every worde w
th
e testim
ony of the
States. And where yo
r
L
p
alledgeth, that they had wrytten to M
r
Caron the
29 of July of their readynes at that tyme to sende away their shipps w
th
o
ut making
any mention of dowbt or delay I have for myne owne discharge expostul
ated with
them, for answearing me in one sorte and their Agent in another: but the
y cleared
the matter p
nt
ly, declaring unto me, that their maner was to deale hones
tly, and
not doubblely, and so they had in
t
matter, shewing me for my better sa
tisfaction
the copie of their l
re
sent to M
r
Caron the 29 of July, w
ch
I hav
e caused
to be translated, and sende yt here unto yo
r
L
p
wherein howsoever M
r
Caron did explicate theyr meaning, there is no such promise made, that t
hey will
sende theyr succors owt of hande, and soe it will appeare by
e issue
of their
dealing. And as touching those dowbts w
ch
they mouved unto me uppon
her
Highnes demaundes, they were onely such as passed by way of co
m
un
ication
betweene them and me, and were not happely sett downe in
t
l
re
to th
eir Agent
because they were not accepted as authenticall demaundes, M
r
Caron
not
knowing neyther at
t
tyme
t
he wryt his l
re
, nor in a good tyme afte
r as he
hath signifyed since, but
t
the countermaunde had stoode. I have
moved
them for 30 last of powder as yo
r
L
p
desyred to have, but the Dep
uties of
Hollande
who are chief in this action being absent from the Haegh
e, the rest
put of theyr aunsweare, till all come togither. I doe wonder very m
uch, that
the taking of
Groninghen
came so lately to yo
r
knowledge, for thag
reement
was made the 11
th
of July, whereof
e newes coming hither the
14 which
was assoone as was possible
M
r
Gilpin
and I dispatched p
nt
ly a
post by
whome he wryt unto yo
r
L
p
and I to
S
r
Robert Cecill
, having othe
rwise
then occasion to sende him a l
re
of
e States, in aunsweare to one
t
was sent
hither from hir Ma
ty
and consigned by him to be
ddl
by me: where
with as
also w
th
that occurrence of Groninghen I did assure myselfe
t
he would
acquaynt yo
r
L
p
. The Post by whome o
r
l
re
s were sent to t
he end he
might prevent all other messengers, albeyt the wynde was very
contrary
hyred purposely a passage for
Yarmouth,
and was the first (as he
affirmeth
and I doe otherwise understande) that brought the tydings into
Englan
d
, and
by him yt was undowbtedly that my
L. of Essex
might knowe the
certainty
and not before, unlesse
t
some body by p
r
sumption had wrytten the new
s before
it was true.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e Haeghe
Au
g
14
1594
